summary: This is a legal document filed in the civil case Jane Doe No. 2 v. Jeffrey Epstein in the Southern District of Florida. It contains Defendant Jeffrey Epstein's formal responses and objections to the plaintiff's amended interrogatories, in which he asserts his Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights and refuses to answer substantive questions about his employees, residences, travel, and other matters related to the alleged abuse. This document is a set of discovery responses and objections filed by Jeffrey Epstein in the civil lawsuit 'Jane Doe No. 2 v. Epstein' (Case No. 08-CV-80119-MARRA-JOHNSON). It includes responses to interrogatories and requests for production, where Epstein asserts his Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights and objects to producing documents related to his criminal cases, insurance, phone records, surveillance, and flight logs. This document is part of a civil lawsuit (Jane Doe No. 2 v. Epstein) and contains the defendant Jeffrey Epstein's responses to the plaintiff's discovery requests. Epstein asserts numerous legal objections and constitutional privileges to avoid producing documents related to his travel, communications with associates, photographs, and other personal records. This document is a certificate of service from a court filing, indicating that copies of a legal document were sent to attorneys representing both the plaintiff (Jane Doe #2) and the defendant (Jeffrey Epstein) on January 26, 2009. It shows the legal representation involved in the case at that time.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein invoked his Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights in response to every interrogatory, refusing to provide any substantive information about employees, visitors, travel, or other matters related to the lawsuit.

The plaintiff's allegations concern a time period 'in or about 2004-2005', but the interrogatories sought information from January 1, 2003, onward, which Epstein's legal team objected to as overbroad.
The interrogatories sought detailed information about individuals who gave or were asked to give massages to Epstein at his residences in Palm Beach, New York, New Mexico, and St. Thomas.
Epstein's legal team objected to questions about his health care providers and sexual aids, citing privilege, HIPAA, and claiming the requests were meant to 'embarrass and harass'.

The document reveals a strategic legal defense by Epstein's attorneys to broadly assert constitutional privileges and object to discovery requests as a means to limit the flow of information in the civil case.

Jeffrey Epstein repeatedly asserts his Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights in response to civil discovery, citing advice from his attorneys that compliance would risk his right to effective representation in related criminal matters.

The discovery requests seek highly sensitive information including: a list of victims from the U.S. Attorney, Epstein's deferred prosecution agreement, his Florida plea agreement, criminal case discovery, telephone records, surveillance from his Palm Beach residence, and flight logs.
Epstein's objections claim the requested documents are privileged, confidential, protected by attorney-client/work product doctrine, overbroad, and implicate the privacy rights of non-parties.
The document references both a 'Federal Criminal Case' and a 'Florida Criminal Case' against Epstein, indicating parallel state and federal investigations.
The plaintiff's allegations are specifically tied to a time period of 'in or about 2004 - 2005'.

Jeffrey Epstein, through his legal team, uniformly objected to 23 separate discovery requests, invoking his Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights, attorney-client privilege, work product doctrine, and a deferred prosecution agreement.

The discovery requests sought highly sensitive material including communications with associates (Haley Robson, Sarah Kellen, Nada Marcinkova, Ghislaine Maxwell, Jean-Luc Brunel), photos/videos of females under 21, travel records, and personal diaries.

Epstein's defense strategy centered on the claim that complying with discovery would force him to waive constitutional rights and risk ineffective assistance of counsel, thus making any adverse inference unconstitutional.

The document reveals the plaintiff was seeking evidence of a pattern of behavior involving young females and modeling agencies, with requests specifically targeting gifts to females under 21 and social media activity.
The case is identified as 'Jane Doe No. 2 v. Epstein', Case No. 9:08-cv-80119-KAM, indicating it is one of several civil suits filed against Epstein by anonymous plaintiffs.
The document is a certificate of service dated January 26, 2009, from a legal proceeding involving Jeffrey Epstein.
The plaintiff in the case is identified as 'Jane Doe #2' and is represented by attorneys Adam D. Horowitz, Jeffrey Marc Herman, and Stuart S. Mermelstein.
Jeffrey Epstein is the defendant, represented by co-counsel Jack Alan Goldberger of Atterbury Goldberger & Weiss, P.A., and the law firm Burman, Critton, Luttier & Coleman.
The document confirms standard legal procedure, showing the active litigation between Epstein and an anonymous accuser (Jane Doe #2) in early 2009.
